A series of 10 wt% NiO-xSiO2-ZrO2 (x = 0–30 wt%) catalysts were synthesized using a one-pot coprecipitation method with different of colloidal SiO2 contents, as a hard template, in order to imprint mesoporous cavities after a post-synthesis selective alkaline NaOH/H2O lixiviation. The final catalysts were characterized by XRD, HRTEM, textural measurements, 29Si-MAS NMR, FTIR, and XPS; the lixiviated, calcined and H2-reduced powders, were evaluated in the decarboxylation (DCO2) of ethyl palmitate as a liquid-solid phase model reaction at 300 °C, and 20 kg/cm2 H2 pressure. Optimal amount of colloidal SiO2 was 10 wt%. SiO2 effect (as colloid in fresh preparations and/or residual SiO2, after lixiviation) on ZrO2 is twofold. (i) to upgrade mesoporosity and (ii) to stabilize the porous structure. Residual SiO2 (from incomplete lixiviation) plays a beneficial role as examined by 29Si-NMR, being chemically bonded to ZrO2 and acting as props of the mesopores. Total pore volume and specific surface area values increased 5 and 6 times, respectively, when using a 30 wt% SiO2 in comparison with a non-silicated NiO-ZrO2 preparation. DCO2 of ethyl palmitate benefit from better mesoporosity and a great number of oxygen vacancies from Ni isomorphic substitution into cubic ZrO2 (as indicated by XPS); being at the origin of the reaction mechanism. For instance, a 10 wt% SiO2 NiO-ZrO2 catalyst is 1.6 times more selective (to n-pentadecane) and 1.2 times more active than a non-silicated NiO-ZrO2, yielding decarboxylated (i.e., deoxygenated) renewable linear hydrocarbons similar to those in a Diesel composition. However, DFT calculations indicate that adsorbed CO2 (as a formate species) desorbs, once fully hydrogenated, as methane regenerating the oxygen vacancies but consuming H2 as well, in agreement with the high methane concentration detected in gas phase. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ethyl palmitate decarboxylation Mesoporous Ni-ZrO2 Oxygen vacancies CO2 Hydrogenation Quantum chemical modelling Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The global growth of oil consumption is the main culprit of the rise in greenhouse gasses (GHG) emissions (mainly CO2 and CH4). Alternatively, reduction in GHG can be achieved replacing fossil fuels with renewable fuels [1]. The production of renewable fuels from biomass-derived feedstocks has gained significant attention due to their potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the depletion of fossil fuels. Also, combustion of biomass-derived fuels represents a cyclic process, since produced CO2 and H2O are raw materials environmentally available for creating new biomass via photosynthesis; in other words, CO2 emissions do not increase the inventory of emissions in the atmosphere [2,3]. Unfortunately, the high oxygen content of biomass-derived compounds is a great handicap for their use as hydrocarbons replacement. The removal of oxygen moieties from these compounds is essential to produce renewable fuels. Different reaction pathways, such as hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), decarbonylation (DCO), and decarboxylation (DCO2), have been explored for the deoxygenation of biomass-derived compounds [4–12]. The HDO of vegetable oils, operates at pressure and temperature like those reported for conventional oil fraction’s hydrotreatment processes (HDT) [13–17], using sulfurized NiMo or CoMo catalysts, which represents a risk of product contamination with sulfur [18,19]. Lamentably, these catalysts deactivate with produced water (i.e., as a byproduct), then, addition of sulfur compounds is required to reactivate the active sites [20]. The DCO removes the carbonyl group in the form of CO and H2O whereas DCO2 is the chemical reaction by which the carboxyl group is removed in the form of CO2 [9]. The DCO and DCO2 eliminate the carbonyl or carboxyl group yielding n-paraffins with one carbon atom less chain long compared with the respective fatty acid [5,13,21]. In agreement with the stoichiometric reaction, the DCO2 does not need the presence of hydrogen to remove the carboxyl group; but instead, it requires a flow of hydrogen to avoid the formation of coke that could be strongly absorbed in the catalyst and deactivate it [22]. The DCO and DCO2 deoxygenation routes represent lower costs due to the lower consumption of hydrogen, compared with the HDO route. The order of lowest to highest hydrogen consumption is as follows: DCO2 <DCO <HDO [9]. For this purpose, Ni has been widely used as a component of HDT catalysts due to its high hydrogenating activity and low cost [9,10,23]. A comparison of Ni deoxygenating activity with that of other metals ranges in the third place only preceded by more expensive noble metals such as Pd and Pt [24]. Accordingly, Ni supported on carbon, Ni/C catalyst, has been studied on the deoxygenation of stearic acid at 300 °C, 9.5 kg/cm2 and 1.5 h, with and without H2 [10]. Only 19% of stearic acid was converted when inert atmosphere was used, whereas by using 10% and 100% volume of H2, conversions of 64% and 80% were reached, respectively [10]. In another approach, Lercher et al. studied the deoxygenation of stearic acid using 10% Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst by varying zeolite’s Si/Al ratio. With a ratio Si/Al= 45, the conversion was 100% and selectivity of 43% toward C17 and C18 paraffins, whereas with a Si/Al= 200 ratio, the selectivity to paraffins increased to 93% [23]. On the other hand, the same authors studied the role of the support by dispersing 10 wt% of nickel in Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 [9,23,25] in the deoxygenation of stearic acid. The Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts reached a conversion of 63% and 45%, respectively. Contrary to what was observed with Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/TiO2 catalysts that attained a conversion of 100% and selectivity of 87% and 96% to C17, respectively. The increase in the catalytic activity was explained assuming the presence of oxygen vacancies in the support generated at the metal-support interface. The development of efficient catalysts for the deoxygenation of biomass-derived compounds is crucial to produce renewable fuels. In recent years, Ni/ZrO2 catalysts have emerged as promising candidates for the deoxygenation of biomass-derived compounds. Ni/ZrO2 catalysts have attracted significant attention due to their ability to promote HDO, DCO, and DCO2 reactions and high catalytic activity and selectivity. In addition, the incorporation of Ni species onto ZrO2 support enhances the catalytic activity and stability. In this regard, different methods have been proposed to generate mesoporosity in non-porous solid catalysts. Hard template method has attracted increasing attention [26] given that this method involves the use of an inorganic material (i.e., colloidal SiO2), which acts as a template (a temporary guest) on which the component oxides of the catalyst are formed around it (the continuous component). The inorganic template can be removed by selective aqueous alkaline treatment leaving imprinted cavities (i.e., mesopores). Fe3C, Co3O4, Al2O3, ZrO2 are some of the mesoporous catalysts prepared by hard template method [26–28]. In this paper we explore a facile one-pot synthesis of NiO-ZrO2, including colloidal SiO2 as temporary template, aiming at improving the porosity of the resulting catalyst, after a soft alkaline removal and a conventional activation procedure. The effect of various concentrations of colloidal SiO2 was also studied. The final catalysts were evaluated in DCO2 of biomass-derived ethyl palmitate as a model compound. Efforts to correlate catalysts characterization results with DCO2 performance prompted us to propose a reaction scheme and to visualize the nature of the active sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were obtained from commercial suppliers: nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (≥99%), zirconium nitrate hydrate (≥99%), colloidal silica (Grace Davison), ammonium hydroxide (30%), ethyl palmitate (≥99%) and dodecane (≥99%). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were synthesized by a co-precipitation method, using colloidal silica as template. An appropriate amount of colloidal silica (12–15 nm diameter) was first dispersed in 100 mL of double distillate water, solution A, in order to obtain 10 and 30 wt% of SiO2 on the final material. In another container, 3.90 g of Ni(NO3).6 H2O and 16.90 g of ZrO(NO3)2.xH2O were dissolved in 500 mL of double distilled water, solution B. Then a solution C was prepared adjusting the concentration of NH4OH solution at 20 vol% by adding double distillate water. Thereafter, solution B and C were added dropwise simultaneously into the solution A maintaining constant pH at 9.5. The resulting suspension was aged for 18 h, then it was filtered, and washed with alkaline solution (NH4OH) at pH 9. Subsequently, the resulting solid was dried at 120 ºC and calcined at 650 ºC in air atmosphere during 4 h. In order to create the mesoporosity, hard template, i.e., colloidal silica, was removed by leaching process with an alkaline 1 M NaOH solution at pH 13.5. Then, it was washed again with alkaline NH4OH solution to remove residual sodium and finally it was dried at 120 ºC. The catalysts synthesized were labeled as NiZrSi-X where X indicates the wt% of colloidal silica. A Ni-ZrO2 catalyst without using SiO2 as hard template was prepared as a reference. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Differential thermal analysis (DTA) was developed on Perkin–Elmer device ATD 1700. Weight loss curve was determined by Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) with a Perkin–Elmer TG-7. The heating rate was 10 °C/min, from room temperature to 1000 °C and flowing air at 20 cm3/min. Morphological and structural characterization was performed by electron microscopy using a scanning electron microscope (Nova NanoLab DualBeam FEI) and a transmission electron microscope (JEM-2200FS), which operate at 200 kV with a polepiece of ultrahigh resolution and an omega filter. Elemental chemical composition was obtained by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy in spectrometers EDAX and Bruker attached to the microscopes, respectively. For the transmission electron microscopy analysis, the sample was first ground in an agate mortar, and thereafter the fine powders were added into isopropanol and dispersed under ultrasonic agitation. Then, an aliquot of this solution was deposited on a 200-mesh copper grid covered with a polymeric thin film. The crystal structure of the samples was characterized by X-ray diffraction in a SIEMENS diffractometer model D-500, coupled with an X-ray copper tube, Kα= 1.5406. The equipment operates at 40 kV voltage and 40 mA of current intensity. The X-ray patterns were acquired in a range of 4 to 80°, with step size 2θ= 0.02°. FT-IR studies were carried out in a Perkin Elmer model Spectrum 100 series equipment, with a spectral frequency range of 650–4000 cm−1. The analysis was carried out at room temperature in transmittance mode, with a resolution of 1 cm−1. NMR-MAS 29Si analysis were acquired in a Bruker Avance 400 MHz which work with a 4-millimeter probe. Kaolinite was used as an external reference, having a chemical shift of − 91.2 ppm. Textural properties (surface specific area (SSA), pore size and total pore volume) were determined in an ASAP-2460 equipment in a MicroActive equipment. Prior to the measurements, samples were outgassed at 300 °C with high vacuum during 3 h. The SSA was calculated from adsorption isotherms using the multi-point Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method within a partial pressure P/P0 range from 0.05 to 0.35 [29,30]. The pore size distribution was determined by Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method [31] from the adsorption branch, the pore volume was measured from the total volume of nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 = 0.98–0.99. Reducibility of NiO on catalysts was determined by temperature programed reduction (TPR) analysis performed in a conventional TPR apparatus using a flow of a H2/Ar mixture (70% H2(v/v), 25 cm3/min) at atmospheric pressure and a heating rate of 10◦C/min from room temperature up to 900 °C. To determine H2 consumption apparatus (TCD signal) was previously calibrated with silver oxide. XPS studies were performed using a Escalab 250 Thermo Fisher Scientific spectrometer, with a base pressure of 2 × 10−9 mbar, equipped with a glove chamber with nitrogen atmosphere (used to minimize the oxidation of the reduced catalysts). A photo-monochromatic X-ray source of Al Kα (hv=1486.6 eV) was used for data acquisition. The spectra of each component were fitted using the Thermo Avantage software (v5.957, Copyright 1999–2016). The binding energies (BE) of each component were referenced to adventitious C1s peak at 284.6 eV. The XPS nickel spectra in the Ni 2p3/2 region were deconvolved considering one satellite signal for each Ni 2p3/2 signal and to deconvolve the O 1s spectra, four different species were considered. 2.4 Catalytic test Ethyl palmitate decarboxylation was carried out in a batch reactor (300 mL Parr Autoclave) using powdered NiZrSi-X catalysts. The solids (catalyst mass=0.4 g) were activated by ex-situ reduction in an H2 stream at 500 °C for 1 h. The activated catalyst was recovered into 40 mL of n-dodecane, used as a solvent, then 0.4 g of ethyl palmitate was added. The reaction was carried out at 300 °C and H2 pressure of 20 kg/cm2, during 1 h and continuous stirring at 1000 rpm. The product analyses were carried out by gas chromatography coupled to a mass spectrometer (GC-MS). The conversion and selectivity were calculated using the following equations: Conversion % = Moles of transformed reagent Moles of reagent feed * 100 Selectivity % = Product moles Moles of transformed reagent * 100 2.5 Quantum chemical modeling DFT studies were performed using a ZrO2 surface as a model for the catalyst, and for simplicity a pentadecanoic acid was selected as a model of hexadecanoic acid, Fig. 1. The catalytic system was doped with NiO, and selected the most energetically favorable, Fig. 1. Then, the most reactive crystallographic plane was obtained, and a supercell was built. Molecular geometries for the single and interacting models were fully optimized with cell axes through Density Functional Theory (DFT) energy minimization by using Material Studio (MS) [32] , energy minimization by using the DMol3 code [33,34] GGA/PBE functional [35], the double numerical polarization (DNP) basis set were employed [36]. All predefined parameters were set at the fine accuracy option. The energy band gap, E gap , is defined as: E gap = E LUMO − E HOMO a large E gap indicates low chemical reactivity and a small gap indicates high chemical reactivity [37]. The interaction energies ∆E [38] of the pentanoic acid and the other species on the Ni-ZrO2 catalyst were calculated as: ∆ E = E species , surface − ( E species + E surface ) Where E surface , E species and E species,surface are the total quantum energy of the Ni-ZrO2 surface, the species to interact and the species contained on Ni-ZrO2, respectively. The high absolute value of the interaction energy denotes a strong attraction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Thermal analysis Thermal analysis was used to determine the crystallization temperature of the zirconia in sample NiZrSi-0 without calcination, and the DTA and TGA curves are shown in Fig. 2. Two endothermic events occur at the beginning of the thermal process, see Fig. 2a. The first one at 95 °C, with a weight loss of 12.4%, is attributed to the desorption of physiosorbed water, see Fig. 2b. The second thermal event occurred at 193 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% and comes from the dehydroxylation stage. Once the dehydroxylation process ended, a small exothermic peak can be distinguished at 340 °C, see Fig. 2a, this event could be associated with the crystallization process of NiO species [39]. A very sharp exothermic peak appeared at 634 °C corresponding to the crystallization of cubic phase of zirconia being stabilized by Ni atoms incorporated into the lattice of ZrO2 structure. Accordingly, similar behaviors occurred on zirconia stabilized with CuO, CaO or Y2O3 [39–41]; by introducing cations with lower oxidation state than Zr4+, oxygen vacancies are generated into the structure to maintain charge neutrality. Based on this result, all samples were calcined at 650 °C. A temperature that is slightly higher than the temperature detected in the thermal analysis to promote the crystallization process. 3.1.2 Elemental composition Chemical composition determined by EDXS is summarized in Table 1 indicating all chemical elements detected in calcined and SiO2- leached samples. NiZrSi-0 catalyst, without any colloidal silica, contains around 14 wt% Ni; this content dropped from 14 to 8 wt% as the amount of colloidal silica in each sample increased. On the other hand, a considerable amount of SiO2 was detected after the leaching process, increasing along the colloidal SiO2 content, suggesting that silica was only partially removed upon leaching and at least a fraction of silicon remained either occluded and/or bonded to zirconia and nickel atoms. Accordingly, there are other harsher means of thoroughly extracting SiO2 particles by using concentrated or aqueous HF [42,43] at the expense of extracting Ni2+ and/or ZrO2 (e.g., because of high solubility at low pH), being detrimental when applying as a catalyst. Below we will demonstrate that residual SiO2, in fact, plays a beneficial role in the final catalyst. As well, Na atoms of around 2 wt% remained in sample NiZrSi-30, that is with the highest silica after leaching and washing procedures. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction XRD results are displayed in Fig. 3. The first XRD pattern corresponds to the sample without colloidal silica, NiZrSi-0 shows four main peaks at 30, 35, 50 and 60° on the 2-theta scale, corresponding to the Miller indices (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0) and (3 1 1), of the cubic phase of zirconium oxide JCPDS 49–1645 card. Additionally, two low intensity peaks were detected at 44 and 63° on the 2-theta scale, corresponding to the Miller indices (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) of nickel oxide according to the JCPDS 04–0835 card. Therefore, the NiZrSi-0 is composed mainly of the c-zirconia and c-NiO phases. The formation of the c-zirconia phase at 650 °C indicates that cubic structure of ZrO2 was stabilized by NiO as reported in the literature for NiO and other dopants to stabilize the cubic structure of zirconia such as CaO, CuO, Y2O3 [39–41]. The XRD patterns of the NiZrSi-10 and NiZrSi-30 samples, also included in Fig. 3, show a strong decrease in the crystallinity degree as the silica content increases this suggests a decrease in the crystallite size and/or the generation of two-dimensional defects as grain boundaries in the crystal structure produced by the introduction of SiO2 molecules. A broad peak around 30° in the two-theta scale, reveals the presence of amorphous zircon (ZrSiO4), even though the samples were annealed at 650; crystallization of cubic phase of Ni-ZrO2 was inhibited due to solid state reaction between ZrO2 and SiO2 [44]. In fact, it has been reported that Zr-Si mixed oxides remain amorphous even after calcination at 900 °C [45–47]. The increase of SiO2 wt% on the catalysts hinders the nucleation and growth of the ZrO2 crystalline particles [48]. This strong effect has been ascribed to a good chemical homogeneity resulting from a high mixing degree of Si and Zr [45–47]. Only the XRD pattern of NiZrSi-10 sample showed two additional peaks at 53 and 60° suggesting the presence of both cubic nanocrystalline Ni-ZrO2 and zircon phases, as it will be addressed latter in our HRTEM results. The main structural unit of zircon is a chain of alternating, edge-sharing SiO4 tetrahedral and ZrO2 triangular dodecahedra characterized by empty octahedric cavities. The metal dopants, like Ni, can be accommodated into the zircon network in interstitial positions; it can substitute for either Zr4+ and Si4+ in their lattice positions [49]. These results also indicate that Si atoms remaining after leaching are strongly interacting with ZrO2 and they are not removed during the NaOH leaching process. 3.1.4 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) Surface morphology observed in samples are displayed in SEM micrographs in Fig. 4. The NiZrSi-0 showed an almost flat surface formed by the agglomeration of nanoparticles with sizes around 50 nm (Fig. 4a). SEM micrographs in Figs. 4b–4c show the surface modification of the particles produced after the leaching process of colloidal silica with NaOH solution. A severe surface degradation is appreciated in the SEM micrographs as the silica content increases. The deterioration grade could be associated with the amount of silica molecules or particles removed upon leaching. For instance, the surface of the particles in the NiZrSi-10 sample prepared with the lowest silica concentration shows small cavities and/or pores generated during the silica extraction due to the small amount of silica that remained without reacting with the NiO and ZrO2 molecules, see Fig. 4b. The SEM micrograph shows a surface lightly modified compared with the surface of the particles without silica, Fig. 4a, and severely degraded in NiZrSi-30 prepared with the higher concentration, see Fig. 4c. Huge cavities with a high presence of big pores in the holes are appreciated in the SEM micrograph, indicating high remotion of silica molecules and/or particles, as revealed by the amounts of silicon in the NiZrSi-30 sample after leaching, 11 wt%. In other words, a greater silica remotion a greater surface deterioration is generated, see Fig. 4b-c. 3.1.5 Textural analysis The main purpose of templating colloidal silica into ZrO2−x(OH)x was to, once selectively removed, SiO2 particles would leave a porous imprint or cavities into the resulting ZrO2 structure. With this aim, calcined NiO-ZrO2-(SiO2) and then SiO2-lixiviated would show improved textural properties in comparison with that prepared without any SiO2 addition. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of SiO2-leached and calcined NiO/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. According to the IUPAC classification, all curve shapes were of type IV isotherm, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials [50]. Furthermore, the hysteresis loops on a relative pressure range 0.4–0.99 correspond to H3 type, which are attributed to aggregated particles, leading to slit-shaped pores [50,51]. In the case of NiZrSi-0 sample, synthesized without any hard SiO2-template and used as a reference, the hysteresis occurred at the relative pressure range 0.4–0.75, whereas in samples containing silica, the hysteresis loops opened up to 0.99 increasing considerably the total N2 adsorption volume. This is a strong indication that larger pore sizes were generated by extracting the hard template, even though and as indicated in Table 1, removal of SiO2 was incomplete. This remanent SiO2 may be seen as impurities or hindrances but in fact they act as beneficial props to uphold the resulting mesopores as will be demonstrated in Si29-MAS NMR below. The pore size distribution was plotted from adsorption branch in insert of Fig. 5, show a mesoporous distribution somewhat different than the reference Ni-ZrO2, that is, both smaller and larger mesopores are created when adding and then removing the hard template. The smaller mesopores (between 2 and 5 nm) might be associated with the original ones of Ni-ZrO2 without SiO2, but partially occluded with residual SiO2. The larger mesopores (between 10 and 20 nm) which are close to the initial colloid size (12–15 nm) or corresponding thereof aggregates, form the imbedded-leached SiO2 colloidal particles. However, residual SiO2 (after partial leaching) may be as well located in these large mesopores. These later mesopores are crucial in increasing surface specific area (see Table 2), as well as the total pore volume and consequently upgrade the accessibility to bulky molecules, like ethyl palmitate. When increasing colloidal SiO2 content above 30% (i.e., 50% SiO2) (not shown), large mesopores distribution becomes highly heterogeneous (roughly from 10 to 100 nm) pointing out an agglomeration of several colloidal particles leaving cavities of disordered sizes after leaching. As well, the small mesopores (2–5 nm) disappeared, probably because of occlusion of excess residual SiO2. Specific surface area (SSA) determined by applying BET equation and total pore volume obtained from BJH method, are indicated in Table 2. As expected, SSA increased as the amount of SiO2 content increase, until reaching a maximum at 30 wt% in sample NiZrSi-30. As can be noted in Table 2, SSA increases 6 times with the addition of silica template, from 52 to 312 m2/g in NiZrSi-0 and NiZrSi-30, respectively, whereas the total pore volume increases 5 times. The improvement in textural properties is clearly attributed to the porosity generated upon hard template leaching, which represent an effective feature to increase accessibility to the active sites, as will be discussed below. Nonetheless, too much colloidal SiO2, as in 30 wt% without leaching, results in worsening of textural properties as explained above and pointed out in Table 2. 3.1.6 High-resolution transmission electron microscopy The crystallinity of the particles was analyzed by HRTEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 6. Atomic resolution image of Fig. 6a of the sample, without colloidal silica, shows the atomic ordering in the nanoparticles, indicating a highly crystalline sample as revealed by XRD results. The Fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern obtained from Fig. 6a revealed a d-spacing of 0.283 and 0.180 nm that fit to the {1 1 1} and {2 2 0} planes of the c-ZrO2 structure reported in the JCPDS 04–0835 card, which was viewed along the zone axis [1 1 ̅ 0]. In the NiZrSi-10 sample, the atomic resolution image of Fig. 6b shows a crystal nanoparticle surrounded by an atomic short-range ordering material, typical of the arrangement of amorphous material evidenced by the broad and diffuse halo feature shown in the FFT pattern of Fig. 6b. The crystallographic analysis performed on the crystal nanoparticle revealed the same c-zirconia structure as detected in the NiZrSi-0 sample. The FFT pattern of Fig. 6b showed d-spacing of 0.284 and 0.297 nm that fitted to the {1 1 1} and {0 0 2} planes of the c-ZrO2 structure reported in the JCPDS 04–0835 card. Then, the sample is formed by small crystallites of c-Ni-ZrO2 imbedded in and amorphous material, very possibly composed of O-Si-Ni-Zr atoms. As the silicon concentration increased in the sample, only short-range ordering was detected in the atomic resolution image, showing a highly disordered structure without any sign of nanocrystals or ordered clusters (see Fig. 6c). A diffuse halo feature related to amorphous arrangement was revealed in the FFT pattern displayed in Fig. 6c. In the image, it is not possible to visualize a crystal long-range ordering, which indicates the loss of crystallinity in the particles. The results suggest that the silicon atoms interact strongly with the ZrO2 molecules, inhibiting the ordered growth of the atoms, hindering a crystal growth, and therefore the formation of the c-Ni-ZrO2 phase. Fig. 7 shows the results of the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) analysis performed on the reduced samples. The annular dark field (ADF) image of Fig. 7a of the catalyst without silica does not show clear evidence of metallic Ni nanoparticles on the zirconia crystal surface, such as those observed in samples NiZrSi-10 and NiZrSi-30; see Figs. 7b and 7c. In the catalysts with silica, the Ni ions in the crystalline lattice are segregated during the reduction process, nucleating, and growing as metallic Ni nanoparticles on the surface of the Zr-Si particles. Additionally, as it was appreciated in the particle size distribution plot in Fig. 7d, the metallic Ni nanoparticle size is strongly influenced by the silica concentration in the catalyst. For example, the catalyst NiZrSi-10 revealed an average size of 3.0 ± 0.8 nm, while the NiZrSi-30 catalyst was around 6 ± 2 nm, respectively. 3.1.7 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy Infrared spectra plotted in the range 1500 to 650 cm−1 for all samples are showed in Fig. 8. A broad peak around ∼950 cm−1 was observed for samples containing the silica, which was not appeared in the spectra of the NiZrSi-0 catalyst. This band has been assigned to the vibrating modes of Zr-O-Si bonds [52,53]. The broadening of this band could be associated to overlapping of multiple vibrations such as Si-OH and Si-O-Zr [52–54]. However, a shift in the position of the vibrating band varying from 926 to 951 cm−1, for sample with zero and low residual Si content, NiZrSi-0 and − 10, and samples with higher amount of Silica, NiZrSi-30, suggesting that this variation must be associated to a decrease in number of Zr-O-Si moieties in mixed oxides. In fact, in a sample without removing silica template (NiZrSi-30NL) but thermally treated, the Si—O—Si asymmetric vibrating band occurred at 1040 cm−1, with its corresponding band at ∼791 cm−1 characteristic of the symmetric stretching of Si-O-Si bonds [52,54,55]. Similar variation of Si vibrating bands has been reported for Si-O-Me hetero-linkages (Me=V, Ti or Al), when Si atoms were introduced into the structure of other metal oxides, such as V2O5, TiO2, and Al2O3 [56–58]. Therefore, the variation in the asymmetric vibrating band in FTIR spectra must be associated to the number of coordination of Si atoms with Zr atoms, i.e. higher vibrating band position correspond to Si atoms surrounded four Si atoms Si(OSi)4 and lower vibrating band to a Si atoms neighboring with two or three Zr atoms Si(OZr)x(OSi) where x = 2 or 3, as observed in NMR results (see below). 3.1.8 29Si-MAS NMR To throw light on the nature of residual SiO2 particles (after the alkaline extraction procedure) and to clear out whether these particles were occluded and/ or chemically bonded, 29Si MAS NMR spectroscopy of the catalysts prepared using colloidal silica as template are shown in Fig. 9. The spectrum of the NiZrSi-10 catalyst shows a Q1 peak at chemical shift − 83 ppm corresponding to the Si(OZr)3(OSi) or Si(OH)3(OSi) [59], associated to Si atoms surrounded by just one Si tetrahedron and three O—Zr or OH bonds. In contrast, 29Si NMR spectra of NiZrSi-30 catalyst shows Q2 and Q3 peaks at chemical shifts of ∼ − 88 and 95 ppm indicating that Si atoms are bonded to two and three SiO4 tetrahedra, Si(OZr)2(OSi)2 and Si(OZr)(OSi)3, respectively [59,60]. As comparison, a non-leached NiZrSi-30 sample, was made up mainly of Q4 peak at a chemical shift of ∼ − 110 ppm, corresponding to Si atoms bonded to four Si tetrahedra, Si(OSi)4. However, a shoulder around ∼ − 95 ppm, suggest the presence of some Si atoms in a Q3 environment. From these results, a linear correlation can be stablished between 29Si NMR chemical shift and Si—O—Si FTIR vibrating bands, confirming that variation observed for Si—O—Si bonds in FTIR depend on the number of Si—O—Zr in the coordination sphere of Si atoms, i.e. an Si Q1 environment shows a Si—O—Si vibrating band at 926 cm−1, whereas for Si atoms in mainly Q4 the vibrating band appearing at 1050 cm−1 (see FTIR Fig. 8). In other words, the amount of (SiO-)x bonds attached to surface (ZrO-)y bonds depends on the SiO2 loading. Higher loadings lead to occluded or physically interacting SiO2 particles. 3.1.9 Temperature programed reduction (TPR) TPR studies were carried out on NiZrSi-0, NiZiSi-10 and NiZrSi-30. All samples showed at least three reduction peaks at temperatures below 500 °C, which can be attributed to surface (peaks a) and bulk reduction of large and small NiO particles (peaks b) having weak and strong interaction with the support, respectively [61,62]. As can be seen in TPR Fig. S1, incorporation of Si in samples NiZrSi-10, increased considerably the intensity of the reduction peaks of surface Ni species (peaks a and b below 500 °C), whereas the intensity of the peak at 685 °C decreased (peaks c), which result from the reduction of Ni species in strong interaction stabilizing the cubic structure of ZrO2. In fact and given that the reduction temperature prior to being used as a catalyst was 500 °C, reducibility of Ni species at 500 °C was measured by the H2 consumption. The reducibility percent determined were 32%, 91% and 59% for NiZrSi-0, NiZiSi-10 and NiZiSi-30, respectively. These results suggest that a considerable amount of NiO loaded is reduced at 500 °C in all samples, coexisting both reduced and unreduced Ni atoms on the surface as confirmed by XPS (below). 3.1.10 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Aiming at examining the composition of the surface layer of the catalysts, reduced NiZrSi-X catalysts were further investigated using XPS to provide more information about the oxidation state of the components and as well as the type of oxygen. The core levels of Ni 2p3/2 orbitals are presented in Fig. 10. In all cases, multiple peaks with their corresponding shake-up related satellites signals (dashed lines) were required to fit the Ni 2p3/2 orbital, (see Fig. 10); binding energy (B.E.) are reported in Table 3. Accordingly, the peak at 852.6–852.8 eV has been assigned to the Ni 2p3/2 orbital of metallic Ni0 [63]. Whereas peak at B.E. around 854.1 eV (see Table 3), corresponds to a Ni 2p3/2 orbital of partially reduced Ni δ(+) species into NiO1−x [64,65]. As well, the peak at 854.8 - 856.5 eV correspond to the Ni 2p3/2 orbital from a Ni2+ atom screened by lattice oxygen into NiO particles [64] and the peak at 856.0 - 858.8 eV correspond to Ni 2p3/2 orbital of Ni2+ non-locally screened by other elements included in the atomic framework [66–69]. Then, the latter two contributions have been assigned to Ni2+ into the lattice. Noteworthy in Table 3, in sample NiZrSi-10, Ni atoms were not completely reduced, the B.E of the corresponding reduced Ni species appeared at 854.1 eV, which indicate that partially reduced Ni δ(+) species into NiO1−x were obtained; only the samples NiZrSi-0 and NiZrSi-30 were made up of completely reduced Ni species with Ni 2p3/2 orbital at ca. 852.8 eV. Therefore, the percentage of reduced Ni species to total surface Ni was estimated including partially reduced Ni δ(+) species (see last column in Table 3), surface atomic ratio Ni0/Nitotal. A higher amount of Ni species, at least partially reduced, were detected in sample NiZrSi-10. Apparently, the presence of silicon atoms inhibits the reduction of Ni species probably due to strong interaction with Si and Zr atoms. Additionally, the dispersion of Ni species calculated as surface atomic ratio Ni/(Ni+Zr+Si) follows the same trend as that of reduced Ni species, the higher the Ni dispersion, the higher the reduced Ni species. Thus, a high Ni dispersion was identified in NiZrSi-10 catalyst, which correlate well with catalytic performance during ethyl palmitate deoxygenation reaction, as will be shown below. Fig. 11 shows the XPS spectra of O 1s of reduced NiZrSi-X catalysts. In the sample without Si, NiZrSi-0, only three peaks were required for the best fit. The first peak at 530.1–530.5 eV, has been assigned to oxygen atoms in fully oxidized surroundings of Zr–O–Zr or Ni–O–Zr bonds of metal oxides or mixed of metal oxides in the zirconia lattice [70], the second peak at 531.4–531.9 eV can be assigned to oxygen atoms linked to vacancy sites [39] or terminal oxygen atoms. The third peak around 532–8-533.3 eV has been attributed to M—OH [70–72]. On the other hand, the samples with Si required four peaks for the best fit, the first three peaks are the same of the non-SiO2 sample but differing in the third peak. This peak can be assigned to M–OH and/or Si—O—Si bonds [70–72] and the fourth peak around 534.1–534.8 eV comes from adsorbed water molecules [72]; the contribution of adsorbed water was observed only in samples containing silicon as a fourth peak of the O 1s orbital. In fact, the intensity of peak at 532.8–533.1 eV, increased considerably in samples containing silicon, (NiZrSi-10 and NiZrSi-30) compared with that without silica (NiZrSi-0), see Table 4, then, it can be stablished that in sample without Si, NiZrSi-0, the peak at 532.8 eV comes mainly from M—OH whereas in samples with silicon, the increment of this peak is mainly attributed to the Si—O—Si contribution of Si(OSi)4, Si(OZr)(OSi)3, Si(OZr)2(OSi)2 or Si(OZr)3(OSi) structures as observed by FTIR and NMR [72]. The contribution of O 1s orbital at 531.4–531.9 eV attributed to oxygen vacancy sites increased considerably in samples containing silicon, see Ovac /Olattice atomic ratio on Table 4. The increment of oxygen vacancy sites is due to the amorphization caused by silicon remaining bonded to Zr or Ni after the leaching process, which hinder the crystallization of cubic phase of zirconia phase, as observed in our XRD results. 3.2 Decarboxylation (DCO2) of ethyl palmitate Synthesized catalysts were tested in the DCO2 of ethyl palmitate, as model molecule of fatty oils. Catalysts performance was measured in terms of conversion and selectivity to indicated products and by-products after 1 h of reaction as indicated in Table 5. As can be seen, the main products obtained from all catalysts were n-pentadecane (n-C15), n-hexadecane (n-C16), 1-hexadecene (C16 =) and carboxylic acids, mainly hexadecanoic acid. These results suggest that the reaction proceeds first via Ni-catalyzed hydrogenolysis of a O—C bond of the ester group in ethyl palmitate producing ethane and hexadecanoic acid, in agreement with the energy required to break the O—C bond (85.7 Kcal/mol), being lower than that to break a C—O bond (97.7 Kcal/mol) [73] to produce ethanol and aldehyde (hexadecanal). However, traces of ethanol and hexadecanal were also detected on the liquid product, suggesting that rupture of C—O bond also occur but to a lesser extent. Therefore, both reaction pathways are proposed to occur as a first step for the ethyl palmitate deoxygenation, as can be seen in Scheme 1. Thereafter, hexadecanoic acid reacts in two ways: i) by direct decarboxylation to produce n-C15 and CO2; and ii) by hydrogenation of carboxylate group of hexadecanoic acid to yield hexadecanal and H2O. Then, hexadecanal reacts by two pathways: i) by decarbonylation producing n-C15 and CO and ii) by hydrogenation, yielding 1-hexadecanol. Nonetheless, 1-hexadecanol was not detected, since it remains in a hydrogenation/dehydrogenation equilibrium with hexadecanal [9], and in addition, it undergoes very fast dehydration to yield 1-hexadecene, which is hydrogenated later to produce n-hexadecane, as shown in Scheme 1. In the case of the gas phase, traces of CO2 were detected, whereas the main product was methane, originated from methanation of CO2 and CO with H2, see Table 6. The catalyst prepared without silica, NiZrSi-0, having a well crystallized cubic phase (see XRD in Fig. 3), showed ethyl palmitate conversion of 78.3 mol%, but a considerable amount (17 mol%) of products remained oxygenated as hexadecanoic acid, whereas deoxygenated products were 44.6 mol% of n-C15 via decarboxylation/decarbonylation paths and 21 mol% of C16 from the hydrogenation route. C16 products were mainly 1-hexadecene which indicate that it comes from dehydration of 1-hexadecanol (see Scheme 1), which is in agreement with a hydrodeoxygenation via hydrogenation of the carboxylic acid to aldehyde, which is subsequently hydrogenated to alcohol, as reported elsewhere [23]. The C15/C16 selectivity ratio was 2.1 for NiZrSi-0 catalyst suggesting that deoxygenation proceed largely from decarboxylation-decarbonylation pathways. This catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation, where Ni was incorporated into the structure of ZrO2 stabilizing the cubic phase. Accordingly, substitution of Zr4+ by a metal with lower oxidation state into the ZrO2 lattice stabilize the cubic crystal phase by generating oxygen vacancies into the structure [39–41]. These surface oxygen defects act as adsorption sites of carboxylic acid group, which can be directly decarboxylated desorbing C15 and CO2, or the α-H of the adsorbed carboxylate can be abstracted to form a ketene intermediate which is then hydrogenated by H* species generated by heterolytic dissociation of H2 on oxygen defect sites [74], or on the metallic particles [75,76], to produce the aldehyde (hexadecanal). Then, it is decarbonylated on Ni centers to yield n-C15 and CO [9,23,25]. Although, it has been reported [77] that decarboxylation reaction is unsuccessful to produce deoxygenated products, and it has been established that the carboxyl group need to be reduced to an aldehyde to break off the C-C single bond to eliminate the carbonyl group. In our case, traces of CO2 were detected instead of CO (see Table 6), confirming that the deoxygenation reaction proceeds mainly by direct decarboxylation of the carboxyl group adsorbed on the oxygen-vacant sites generated by introduction of Ni into the ZrO2 cubic structure [9]. Accordingly, decarboxylation is the preferred pathway of palmitic acid conversion over oxygen defect sites of m-ZrO2, whereas it switches to hydrogenation when Ni0 nanoparticles were deposited on it [9,78]. It is important to recall that porosity was generated into well crystallized cubic structure of Ni-ZrO2, (see XRD and HRTEM, Figs. 3 and 6) when the catalyst was prepared using 10 wt% of colloidal silica as hard template, Ni atoms incorporated (isomorphic substitution) into cubic ZrO2 structure are resistant to be reduced (see TPR results, Fig. S1), and more accessible oxygen defects are exposed in comparison with NiZrSi-0 sample synthesized without silica. Residual Si atoms remaining after the leaching procedure are bonded in a Q1 environment (see RMN and FTIR results) preventing the collapse of the porous structure. This catalyst (NiZrSi-10) showed the highest conversion of ethyl palmitate, 94.1 mol%, with only 4.8 mol% selectivity to hexadecenoic acid in contrast to 17 mol%, when using NiZrSi-0 sample. The main deoxygenated products obtained were 70.6 mol% of n-C15 and 5.4 mol% to C16, (n-C16 and C16 =) giving a C15/C16 ratio of 13.1 indicating that the deoxygenation reaction occurs mainly through decarboxylation/decarbonylation path. Evidently, increasing the porosity and SSA resulted in a better diffusion and accessibility of reactants/products inside the catalyst, i.e ethyl palmitate and palmitic acid, to the Ni particles and oxygen vacancy sites generated by introducing Ni atoms into the cubic structure of ZrO2. Some Ni atoms exposed NiZrSi-10 surface were not completely reduced (see XPS, B.E. = 854.1 eV), having a very strong interaction within the structure of the ZrO2 phase and thus, forming oxygen vacancies which are the active sites for decarboxylation/decarbonylation. Therefore, the decarboxylation reaction proceeded mainly through this path. Additionally, a substantial increase in the concentration of methane, from methanation of CO2 [79] and traces of CO2, confirm the improvement of catalytic performance via a decarboxylation pathway. In fact, as will be indicated below in our DFT results, CO2 never desorbs from the O vacancy site, it remains adsorbed as formate specie, and it is hydrogenated until it desorbs as methane. A catalyst prepared with 30 wt% silica, NiZrSi-30, showed lower catalytic activity, where ethyl palmitate conversion was 57.9 mol% and selectivity towards n-C15 and C-16 of 43.2 and 27.6 mol% respectively, giving a C15/C16 ratio of 1.6 and selectivity towards hexadecenoic acid was 16.7 mol%. In spite of NiZrSi-30 having 312 m2/g of SSA, decarboxylation activity was lower than that of NiZrSi-10 catalyst (see Table 5). This fact, can be explained as follows, in NiZrSi-30 catalyst, a larger amount of residual Si remained bonded in a Q2 and Q3 environment, Si(OZr)2(OSi)2 and Si(OZr)(OSi)3, (see NMR results), hindering the crystallization and stabilization of cubic structure of ZrO2 because of Ni (see XRD and HRTEM results). It remained as a microcrystalline or amorphous phase, then the increment observed in the amount of O vacancy sites (see XPS, Table 4) comes from the amorphous phase instead of the ZrO2 stabilized structure, the surface Ni atoms interaction with the amorphous Zr-Si-O phase is weaker than that when in isomorphic substitution in cubic ZrO2 structure, so Ni is reduced (see XPS, Table 3). In other words, there are not enough vacant NiZrO2 active sites to carry on decarboxylation/decarbonylation of palmitic acid. In fact, the C15/C16 selectivity ratio dropped from 13.1 to 1.6 in NiZrSi-10 and NiZrSi-30, respectively, suggesting that the reaction proceeds in larger extend via hydrogenation on metallic Ni particles in sample NiZrSi-30. Finally, a non-lixiviated NiZrSi-30 sample (NiZrSi-30NL) was evaluated as reference, in order to clear out the importance of porosity. As can be seen in Table 5, a lower ethyl palmitate conversion was attained compared with a lixiviated NiZrSi-30 catalysts and the other catalysts. Here, the major product obtained was palmitic acid, and in turn a little amount of this carboxylic acid was deoxygenated to paraffins C15 and C16, giving a selectivity ratio of n-C15/C16 of 0.3, which indicate that reaction proceeds mainly by a hydrogenation path. These results suggest that the porosity generated by silica extraction contribute to the diffusion of ethyl palmitate and palmitic acid into the internal active sites of the particles and that Ni introduced into the amorphous Zr-Si-O phase orient the reaction through the hydrogenation path. Furthermore, by comparing the catalytic activity of non-lixiviated NiZrSi-30NL with that of NiZrSi-10, it can be concluded that porosity is required but more important is to maintain a cubic ZrO2 structure stabilized by Ni, where oxygen vacancies generated act as active sites to catalyze the deoxygenation via decarboxylation or decarbonylation paths (see Scheme 1). Accordingly, the most important parameter on ethyl palmitate deoxygenation reaction is the presence and proximity of reduced or partially reduced Ni particles and oxygen surface vacancies of cubic structure of ZrO2 stabilized by Ni, in agreement with the findings of M. López et at [80]. Oxygen vacancies, generated by the introduction of Ni atoms into the cubic structure of ZrO2, have been proposed as the adsorption sites [9,75,76,80]. Whereas the homolithically dissociated protons, H* , required for the reaction come from adjacent Ni metal centers. For deoxygenation reactions, both vacancies and metal centers are necessary. Here in, it is hypothesized that well reduced Ni particles (Ni0) such as those observed in NiZrSi-0 and NiZrSi-30, provide dissociated protons more efficiently than in partially reduced (Ni δ(+)) detected on NiZrSi-10. Therefore, NiZrSi-0 and NiZrSi-30 samples exposing zero-valent Ni0 atoms catalyze HDO reaction through hydrogenation path requiring a larger amount of hydrogen to be desorbed as C16 molecules. In contrast, NiZrSi-10 expose partially reduced Ni δ(+), develops the deoxygenation reaction via decarboxylation. Therefore, decarboxylation requires less amount of H2 to be desorbed as C15. Nevertheless, the -COOH formate species remain bonded to Zr atoms on the surface in agreement with our DFT results. Finally, the mesoporosity imprinted by SiO2 leaching process favors the diffusion of reactants/products inside the catalyst, allowing accessibility to oxygen vacancies and Ni particles. 3.3 Quantum chemical modeling HRTEM analysis (see above) revealed the crystal planes seen along to the < 110 > zone axis, parallel to the electron beam, exhibiting (100) and (111) surfaces on the edge of the c-NiZrO2 crystals in HRTEM image. With a view to look for the most reactive crystal plane of Ni-substituted ZrO2 and taking into account the generation of oxygen vacancies as indicated by XPS (see above), a quantum chemical modeling study was carried on. After attempting several cell doping strategies with NiO, the more energetically favorable configuration, see Table 7 and Fig. 12, was doped with 1 Ni atom in the corner of the system (Zr3O7Ni1 stoichiometric configuration). The boundary molecular orbitals HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) and LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) were obtained in undoped and in Ni doped ZrO2 bulks, Fig. 13. In undoped bulk, HOMO is distributed mainly in the O atoms, whereas LUMO is mainly found in the Zr atoms. In Ni doped ZrO2 bulk, HOMO is located mainly in the Ni dopant atom and LUMO is in the Ni atom and in the oxygen atoms. This means that doped with Ni into ZrO2, changes the ability of O atoms from electron donors in undoped ZrO2 to electron acceptors in Ni doped ZrO2, whereas the ability to accept electrons remain around Zr and Ni atoms mainly. As the doping atom is exposed in the bulk, it was considered the crystallographic plane that this atom is exposed, and for the symmetry we selected the (1 0 0) plane, Fig. 14a. A simulation cell (SC) was built with dimensions asc= 10.140, bsc= 10.140 and csc= 21.337 Å, obtained as a 2 × 2 × 1 supercell from the system of ZrO2, the vacuum space was 15 Å. As the bulk was grown twice, and according with the Egap, Fig. 14b, the most reactive system is the one with only one atom doping and, in the corner, for that reason this supercell was promoted twice, and this atom was over the surface and generated two vacancies. The simulated [1 0 0] plane was placed in contact with the pentanoic acid, Fig. 15, the OH group of the carboxylic acid occupies the oxygen vacancy site, and the H is bonded to the Ni atom. The other oxygen of carboxylic acid is attached to two neighboring Zr atoms, once the interaction was complete. The initial double bond O═C of carboxylic acid, changed its position to the oxygen initially as OH group, Fig. 15a, the resulted interaction energy was − 40.174 kcal/mol. Thereafter, H2 molecule was added to the system, and it dissociated, breaking the C—C bond of the carboxylic acid, releasing butane and leaving a bidentate formate specie HCOO* bonded to the surface, as indicated in Fig. 15b. The interaction energy was − 50.168 kcal/mol. When increasing the presence of H2 molecules, the hydrogenation of the adsorbed formate specie continues passing by dioxymethylene H2COO* and methoxy H3CO* intermediate species, Fig. 15c-d, until it desorbs as methane, Fig. 15e, with a final interaction energy of − 211.472 kcal/mol. These results clarify our experimental findings, that once the ester i.e., ethyl palmitate, has been converted into the carboxylic acid, i.e. palmitic acid, deoxygenation occurs by the adsorption of the carboxylic acid on the oxygen vacancy site, where the two oxygen atoms of the carboxylic acid are bonded to Ni and Zr close to the vacancy and the other one to two neighbor Zr atoms, thereafter hydrogenation of OOC—C bond occurs releasing an alkane lacking one carbon moiety (n-C15) and the CO2 remain strongly adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy site as a formate specie (HCOO*). The hydrogenation of formate species continues transforming into dioxymethylene and methoxy species until they are desorbed as methane. In summary, upon decarboxylation on Ni-ZrO2 catalyst, the CO2 do not desorb, it remains strongly adsorbed as HCOO- formate specie, where is later hydrogenated and desorb as methane, explaining the increment of methane concentration in the gas-phase when n-C15 increased mainly on NiZrSi-10 catalysts. Accordingly, and by using DFT calculations, adsorbed formate species is the intermediate moiety when hydrogenating CO2 with H2 to obtain methanol on a CuO-ZrO2 catalyst [81]. 4 Conclusions When developing solid catalysts for decarboxylation of long-chain fatty acids esters (i.e. ethyl palmitate), three main features are crucial for upgrading catalytic performance: i) adequate mesoporosity, ii) oxygen vacancies generated by a low valent reducible NiOx, and iii) available (100) crystal planes of Ni-doped ZrO2, being the most reactive one, according to quantum chemical modeling. Larger mesopores imprinted by hard templating ZrO2 with colloidal SiO2 allow a better diffusion and more effective contact of bulky esters with the active sites. Isomorphic substituted Ni2+ into ZrO2 plays two fundamental roles: i) stabilizing ZrO2 cubic phase and, ii) promoting the number of oxygen vacancies. Tuning mesopores size and distribution yields a NiO-ZrO2 (NiZrSi-10) catalyst 6.2 times more selective to decarboxylation/decarbonylation n-pentadecane than to hydrogenation of C16 hydrocarbons in comparison with a non-silicated NiO-ZrO2 (NiZrSi-0). Both linear n-alkanes are within a conventional Diesel composition. The advantage of selectively orienting towards decarboxylation (i.e n-pentadecane) versus hydrogenation (i.e., n-hexadecane) is based on hydrogen consumption; H2 being scarce and expensive. The decarboxylation route uses one molecule of H2 and while hydrogenation needs 3–4 molecules. Nonetheless and according to our DFT results, H2 is consumed by the adsorbed intermediate formate species until it desorbs as methane, restoring the active site as an oxygen vacancy. coredata.dc:description: A series of 10 wt% NiO-xSiO2-ZrO2 (x = 0–30 wt%) catalysts were synthesized using a one-pot coprecipitation method with different of colloidal SiO2 contents, as a hard template, in order to imprint mesoporous cavities after a post-synthesis selective alkaline NaOH/H2O lixiviation. The final catalysts were characterized by XRD, HRTEM, textural measurements, 29Si-MAS NMR, FTIR, and XPS; the lixiviated, calcined and H2-reduced powders, were evaluated in the decarboxylation (DCO2) of ethyl palmitate as a liquid-solid phase model reaction at 300 °C, and 20 kg/cm2 H2 pressure. Optimal amount of colloidal SiO2 was 10 wt%. SiO2 effect (as colloid in fresh preparations and/or residual SiO2, after lixiviation) on ZrO2 is twofold. (i) to upgrade mesoporosity and (ii) to stabilize the porous structure. Residual SiO2 (from incomplete lixiviation) plays a beneficial role as examined by 29Si-NMR, being chemically bonded to ZrO2 and acting as props of the mesopores. Total pore volume and specific surface area values increased 5 and 6 times, respectively, when using a 30 wt% SiO2 in comparison with a non-silicated NiO-ZrO2 preparation. DCO2 of ethyl palmitate benefit from better mesoporosity and a great number of oxygen vacancies from Ni isomorphic substitution into cubic ZrO2 (as indicated by XPS); being at the origin of the reaction mechanism. For instance, a 10 wt% SiO2 NiO-ZrO2 catalyst is 1.6 times more selective (to n-pentadecane) and 1.2 times more active than a non-silicated NiO-ZrO2, yielding decarboxylated (i.e., deoxygenated) renewable linear hydrocarbons similar to those in a Diesel composition. However, DFT calculations indicate that adsorbed CO2 (as a formate species) desorbs, once fully hydrogenated, as methane regenerating the oxygen vacancies but consuming H2 as well, in agreement with the high methane concentration detected in gas phase.
coredata.dc:title: Ethyl palmitate decarboxylation using colloidal SiO2- templated mesoporous Ni-ZrO2 catalysts
